importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the previous government shutdown, which began on December 22, 2018, and lasted 35 days, making it the longest in history.
The end date of the previous government shutdown, which ended on January 25, 2019, marking a 35-day closure.
The current update date of the article, indicating ongoing coverage of a new government shutdown as of October 21, 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The duration of the longest government shutdown in U.S. history, lasting 35 days, from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019.
The current government shutdown, which began with the failure to pass any of the 12 appropriations bills, and remains ongoing as of October 21, 2025, indicating a full shutdown.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown in U.S. history, which lasted 35 days from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019, was the longest in nearly 50 years and cost an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP.
The current shutdown is a full shutdown, meaning no appropriations bills have been passed, unlike the 2018 partial shutdown where only some agencies were funded.
During the 2018 shutdown, approximately 800,000 federal employees were affected, with about 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted but unpaid.
A full government shutdown occurs when Congress fails to pass all 12 appropriations bills needed to fund federal operations.
Partisan gridlock in Congress, including a narrow House majority and lack of Senate filibuster-breaking votes, has prolonged the inability to pass funding agreements.
Government shutdowns have become less common since 1990, with only six occurring since 1990, but increasing political polarization has made resolution more difficult.

namedEntities.name: United States federal government
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The national government of the United States, which is currently shut down.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The entity is central to the article as it describes the current and previous shutdowns, highlighting disruptions to public services and economic costs.

namedEntities.name: Congress
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The legislative body in the United States responsible for passing funding legislation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Congress failed to pass appropriations bills, leading to the shutdown, and its partisan divisions are emphasized as a root cause of the impasse.

namedEntities.name: Capitol Hill
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The site of Congress in Washington, D.C., where legislative debates and negotiations take place.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The shutdown is described as being due to stalled negotiations on Capitol Hill, indicating political deadlock in the legislative process.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Republican Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His leadership and the narrowest House majority in history are cited as contributing to the difficulty of passing funding bills and avoiding a shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Senate filibuster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A procedural rule in the U.S. Senate allowing prolonged debate to block legislation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The GOP lacks the 60 votes needed to end a filibuster, which hinders the passage of spending bills and contributes to ongoing shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nonpartisan office that provides economic and fiscal analysis to Congress.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The CBO estimated the economic cost of the 2018 shutdown at $3 billion in lost GDP, providing a quantitative assessment of the impact.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Funding legislation required to fund all federal departments and agencies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The failure to pass these bills is the direct cause of the current full government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: furloughed employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal workers who were not paid and instructed not to report to work during shutdowns.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 2018 shutdown affected about 300,000 furloughed employees, illustrating the human cost of government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: exempted employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal workers who were required to report to work but did not receive pay during shutdowns.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: In the 2018 shutdown, about 500,000 exempted employees worked without pay, showing the operational strain on federal agencies.

namedEntities.name: Gillian Roberts and Kaanita Iyer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: CNN journalists who authored the article.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are the sources of the article, providing coverage and context on the current and historical government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Tami Luhby
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: CNN reporter who provides updates on which services are affected during the shutdown.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She contributes real-time information on which government services are continuing or halting during the shutdown.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. federal government is currently in a full shutdown due to Congress failing to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills. This is a significant escalation from the 2018 shutdown, which was partial and lasted 35 days—the longest in nearly 50 years—costing an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP. During that prior shutdown, around 800,000 federal employees were affected, with 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted from pay. The article attributes the ongoing impasse to deepening political polarization, a narrow Republican majority in the House led by Speaker Mike Johnson, and the Senate’s ability to block legislation via filibuster, preventing passage of funding bills. The article highlights that while government shutdowns have become less frequent since 1990, increasing partisan dynamics have made resolving funding disputes increasingly difficult.
